name: thedailybeast
text:
On March 9, long before it was clear that COVID-19 might be airborne, Diana Zicklin Berrent attended a meeting.

“Everyone at the meeting was infected with the coronavirus, and one died of it 2 weeks later.”
https://t.co/sHV0fjpgDM

name: thedailybeast
text:
In an update to its website, the CDC confirmed what has long been suspected
https://t.co/62EaoK0qS8

name: thedailybeast
text:
Berrent had what she called the “Tylenol and Gatorade” version of the virus. She never had to be hospitalized and she recovered. She got lucky.

“Or so I thought.” 

https://t.co/R94XjB1Mfq

name: thedailybeast
text:
Six months later, this COVID “survivor” still hasn’t been able to exercise and she still experiences “deep inner-ear pain and excruciating headaches.” And now she’s been diagnosed with glaucoma, possibly connected to COVID-19.

https://t.co/R94XjB1Mfq

name: thedailybeast
text:
“What are we to make of these ‘survivors’ who are 4, 5, 6 months into their recovery and mere shadows of their former selves?” 

https://t.co/R94XjB1Mfq

name: thedailybeast
text:
Berrent started a movement called Survivor Corps that now acts as a patient advocacy group.

“And there are a lot of us who need help.”

Read more: https://t.co/R94XjB1Mfq
